General.name: Kai Parker
General.label: Coastal Scientist
General.summary: Innovative coastal scientist with over a decade of experience in coastal hazard modeling, climate adaptation, and stakeholder-driven science across the U.S. West Coast. Proven leader in developing and managing multi-million-dollar projects at the USGS, with a strong foundation in numerical modeling, geospatial analysis, and nature-based solutions. Adept at translating complex data into actionable insights for diverse audiences, from policymakers to local communities. Passionate about mentoring, cross-disciplinary collaboration, and advancing coastal resilience through science-based planning and communication.

work.name: United States Geological Survey
work.summary: Technical lead for coastal hazard modelling in the Pacific Northwest
highlights: Managed team and budget (external funding totaling >4 million) for large project (CoSMoS) delivering actionable coastal hazard data impacting populations in the millions
Lead collaboration with multiple partners and engagement with diverse stakeholders including tribes, counties, communities, and federal and academic partners.

work.name: United States Geological Survey
work.summary: Coastal Hazard and Coastal Science under climate change
highlights: Designed coastal modelling workflows allowing a small team to develop multi-hazard datasets at regional scales (entire Southeast Atlantic).
Developed data pipelines to efficiently process 30+ TB of data into stakeholder-ready products.
Work on adaptation solutions to address ecosystem degradation and coastal hazard risk.

work.name: Fulbright Chile
work.summary: International exchange postdoc working in Valparaiso Chile on coastal erosion
highlights: Application of machine learning techniques for long-term wave and shoreline change hindcasting in resource poor (computational and data) environments.
Contributed to adaptation planning efforts for a critical Chilean coastal site (Pichilemu).

work.name: Oregon State University
work.summary: Multiple projects bridging from stakeholder centered adaptation to physical model and developing new machine learning methods
highlights: User-centered design, bridging research to stakeholders for community adaptation to risk.
Large interdisciplinary team including public policy, economics, ecology, and more.
Developed new hybrid machine learning/physical modeling methodology for robust probabilistic coastal hazard assessments.

work.name: Moffatt & Nichol
highlights: Comprehensive analysis of various coastal phenomenon such as shoreline erosion, sediment budgets, river/estuary modeling, sea level rise, etc.
Extensive technical writing explaining coastal processes at multiple audience levels.
